headline: Opinion | Tariffs, immigration, and Trump’s First 100 Days: 14 Former Democratic Voters Discuss - The New York Times
context: To state the obvious, a lot of Democrats loathe President Trump, and a lot of Republicans love him. What about people who used to vote Democratic but decided last November to take a flier on Mr. Trump for the first time? Why did they swing to him? How do they think it’s working out? And what can the Democratic Party do to win them back?

For our latest Times Opinion focus group, we wanted to see Mr. Trump’s first 100 days through the eyes of Americans who — yearning for change, for something to be hopeful about, for someone to fix the economy and immigration — voted for him. We wanted to explore the nature of optimism and regret in politics, what they saw as his successes and failures, why they were drawn to him and what, if anything, has put them off.

annotations.paragraph: And some of these voters do have regrets. The focus group conversation was a window into the way many of us think: We want something different from what we have, we become especially tantalized by the idea of action, and we are willing to tell ourselves stories — for example, that Mr. Trump was a businessman who would be better for the economy than Kamala Harris — to rationalize taking a risk, voting for a candidate who promised to subject a growing economy to an enormous gamble on tariffs.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides insight into the mindset of voters who switched to Trump, which is relevant to understanding their motivations and regrets.

annotations.paragraph: “My life wasn’t getting better. The future wasn’t looking great,” said Meagan, a 37-year-old small-business owner from Texas, explaining why she switched from voting for Democrats to voting for Mr. Trump in 2024. Now she is toggling between hope that the tariffs lead somewhere positive and fear about her business being hammered by the economy and those trade policies.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a specific example of a voter's reasoning and current concerns, directly related to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: It’s hard for a lot of us to talk about regret or admit we were wrong. Most of these 12 voters still want their bet on Mr. Trump to pay off, a hope made easier by the fact that few see the Democrats as an appealing alternative. How can Mr. Trump or the Democrats make them happy? They have plenty to say on that, too.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses the voters' ongoing hopes and perceptions of political alternatives, which is relevant to the article's exploration of their views.

annotations.paragraph: In 2016 and 2020, you voted for the Democratic presidential candidate, but in 2024 you all switched to Donald Trump. I think you are the reason Donald Trump is president. Give me a sentence describing what you thought of Donald Trump on the day you voted for him in 2024 and what you think of him nearly 100 days in.
annotations.reason: This paragraph sets up a direct question to the voters, which is relevant to understanding their perspectives.

annotations.paragraph: I just felt more comfortable with him last November, his policies. Now he’s biting off a little bit more than I think he should.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a voter's personal reflection on their changing perception of Trump, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: I was excited when I voted for him, but I worried that he would go too far. Today there are a lot of positive things happening.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a personal perspective on the voter's initial excitement and current view of positive developments.

annotations.paragraph: I was a little skeptical when I voted, stuck between two bad choices, but hopeful that maybe Trump was a different person now. Overall, I’m disappointed. He hasn’t accomplished what he set out to do, and the economy is not moving in the right direction.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers insight into the voter's skepticism, hope, and current disappointment with Trump's performance.

annotations.paragraph: I felt Trump was the better candidate. Now I think he has good intentions, but he’s going about it the wrong way.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a personal assessment of Trump's intentions and methods.

annotations.paragraph: I was truly hoping that Trump was looking for some redemption for his past efforts. I really thought that was going to happen.
annotations.reason: This paragraph reflects the voter's initial hope for Trump's redemption, contributing to the narrative of voter sentiment.

annotations.paragraph: And now?
annotations.reason: The paragraph is too vague and does not provide any substantial information.

annotations.paragraph: He’s doing undeniably, unequivocally awful.
annotations.reason: This is a vague generalization without specific context or detail.

annotations.paragraph: I was disappointed on Election Day. Disappointed in the whole process. Today I want Trump to pump the brakes on some stuff. Sometimes it seems like we’re just sort of shooting from the hip. I don’t think we can govern like that.
annotations.reason: This provides direct commentary on the voter's perspective on Trump's governance style.

annotations.paragraph: When I voted, I was hopeful that things were going to be better. Today I’m seeing some progress, but I’m also a little nervous.
annotations.reason: This reflects the voter's mixed feelings and provides insight into their current perspective.

annotations.paragraph: In November, I needed change, especially with immigration. I think he’s doing a wonderful job. The only thing that’s holding him back is all these lawsuits. It’s going to handcuff him.
annotations.reason: This offers specific commentary on immigration and perceived obstacles to Trump's policies.

annotations.paragraph: It’s fine to have opinions on immigration. I believe in good Republican politics. Taking people idly off the street because you think they might be a gang member doesn’t fly with me. Due process is for all, no matter what the situation is. You want to deport somebody, they deserve due process.
annotations.reason: This provides a specific opinion on immigration policy and due process.

annotations.paragraph: Daniel, why do you regret your vote?
annotations.reason: This is a question prompting a response, not providing new information.

annotations.paragraph: My 401(k) keeps on dropping. That’s bad. Some people don’t want to pretend it’s bad because a large portion of this country does not have stocks. Most of MAGA doesn’t have stocks, so they don’t care.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a personal perspective on economic concerns related to Trump's presidency.

annotations.paragraph: I was tentative on Election Day. I wasn’t sure that Trump was the better candidate, and now I’m pretty sure that he is not the one. I regret the choice. I think that he’s just taken executive power way too far, and it’s just obliterated the legislative and congressional side of things for our government. We only have executive orders now.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers insight into the voter's regret and perception of Trump's governance style.

annotations.paragraph: How would you describe Donald Trump’s approach to governing?
annotations.reason: This is a question prompting a response, not providing new information.

annotations.paragraph: Just as chaotic as it was before. Fool me on that.
annotations.reason: This provides a brief opinion on Trump's governance style, relevant to the discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Extremely aggressive. In some cases too aggressive, and in others it has actually worked out well.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct opinion on Trump's approach, relevant to the discussion of his first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: He is diplomatic, but he also crosses the line at times.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a perspective on Trump's diplomatic style, relevant to evaluating his performance.

annotations.paragraph: I think he can be vindictive and difficult to deal with personally as president. And I think he can be very tough to deal with.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a personal opinion on Trump's character, relevant to the discussion of his presidency.

annotations.paragraph: With Washington as divided as it is right now, if he’s not determined, it’ll get bogged down. The way he’s trying to push it through, at least he can initiate and get the ball rolling, instead of being in a quagmire for the next two years.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses Trump's determination and its impact on political progress, relevant to his first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: What is or has been Donald Trump’s greatest success in these first 100 days?
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a question for discussion, relevant to evaluating Trump's early presidency.

annotations.paragraph: Immigration. He’s been getting what he calls violent offenders out and will not allow anybody to come in. Being here in Illinois, Chicago, it’s been a hot mess here.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific opinions on Trump's immigration policies from a former Democratic voter.

annotations.paragraph: He’s almost all but completely stopped the flow of immigrants into this country. And then he’s gone out and been pretty aggressive with removing people that don’t belong here.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a perspective on Trump's immigration actions, relevant to the discussion of his first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: The border has basically been shut down. If you’re going to do it legally, I have no problem with it. But you’ve got a lot of criminals over here. We need to get rid of them.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a viewpoint on immigration policy, relevant to the article's focus on Trump's first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: Daniel, I know that you regret your vote. But do you think he’s been OK on immigration?
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a question about a voter's regret and views on immigration, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Well, no. He’s been a success at creating a quagmire of confusion.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct opinion on Trump's immigration policy, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: How so?
annotations.reason: This is a vague question without context or information.

annotations.paragraph: I think he’s done a tremendous job.
annotations.reason: This is a general opinion without specific context or details.

annotations.paragraph: I agree.
annotations.reason: This is a brief agreement without additional information.

annotations.paragraph: He said what he was going to do, and he’s doing it.
annotations.reason: This provides a perspective on Trump's fulfillment of promises.

annotations.paragraph: I would never want a person to be deported inappropriately. Like, if they’re a citizen and we’ve accidentally deported them to another country, obviously, that’s terrible.
annotations.reason: This provides a specific opinion on immigration policy.

annotations.paragraph: I don’t think that’s going to happen.
annotations.reason: This statement is vague and does not provide specific information or context related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: From my understanding, that’s happening a lot.
annotations.reason: This is a vague statement that lacks specific information or context related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The quagmire of confusion that I’m talking about is that right now, we’re having a fight between who has more power — the justices or the president — over this immigration deal. If you don’t see that, you’re blind, 100 percent.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific commentary on the power struggle over immigration policy, which is relevant to the discussion of Trump's first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: Daniel, over the last administration, we had millions of illegals come across the border. How many years would it take to process them all with due process to get them back out of the country?
annotations.reason: This paragraph raises a specific issue related to immigration policy, which is relevant to the article's focus on Trump's first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: If we went and looked at each one of those people who were arrested, you would find more and more that were American citizens, I guarantee you.
annotations.reason: This statement provides a perspective on immigration enforcement, which is relevant to the article's focus on immigration during Trump's first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: No, there’s none that are American citizens.
annotations.reason: The paragraph is a low-information quote that does not contribute to the main discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Daniel, I agree with you.
annotations.reason: This is a low-information agreement statement that does not add to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Chris, you said you hoped Trump would be different this time in office. Help our readers understand why you expected anything different from Trump.
annotations.reason: This paragraph sets up a question that prompts a relevant discussion about expectations of Trump.

annotations.paragraph: I saw a lot of discipline from candidate Trump, and I think that was a real surprise, given how he had acted in prior elections. And so you thought, “Wow, maybe this guy has changed. Maybe he’s taking things more seriously.” And I think coming in as president, I just really haven’t seen that. The chaos around the tariffs is a great example.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the voter's expectations and perceptions of Trump's presidency.

annotations.paragraph: I voted for him because I also thought he was very focused, and maybe he had learned from the previous term that he had in the presidency. Immigration aside, my problem is his pick of cabinet secretaries for his administration.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a voter's reasoning for supporting Trump and their concerns, contributing to the main discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Did you expect him to pick different kinds of cabinet secretaries when you voted for him?
annotations.reason: The question is relevant as it addresses expectations versus reality regarding Trump's cabinet choices.

annotations.paragraph: Yes. I felt that he would have learned lessons in the last administration. The secretary of defense is not competent. He may be good-looking, and he may be a Fox host, but that shouldn’t be criteria.
annotations.reason: This response provides a specific opinion on Trump's cabinet choices, contributing to the discussion of his first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: I just didn’t expect so much so fast. I just feel like there’s so many things happening every day in the news. I didn’t expect to have to be so politically oriented every day, watching the news for the next policy change or initiative or vindictive action or executive order.
annotations.reason: This paragraph reflects on the pace and impact of Trump's actions, relevant to evaluating his first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: Where has Donald Trump failed the most in the first 100 days?
annotations.reason: The question is relevant as it seeks to identify perceived failures in Trump's early presidency.

annotations.paragraph: The biggest failure is immigration, in my mind.
annotations.reason: This statement directly addresses a perceived failure in Trump's first 100 days, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: The volatility in the market right now.
annotations.reason: This is a vague statement without specific context or details related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: I’d have to agree with the volatility in the market. And my hope is that it’s growing pains.
annotations.reason: This is a general statement without specific context or details related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Still thriving on his arrogance.
annotations.reason: This is a vague and subjective statement without specific context or details related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The stock market and the economy.
annotations.reason: This is a vague statement without specific context or details related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The dollar hasn’t been this low in a very long time.
annotations.reason: This is a specific economic observation that could relate to the discussion of Trump's impact.

annotations.paragraph: I think the tariff situation was a pretty big failure.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct opinion on Trump's tariff policy, relevant to the discussion of his first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: I’m not sure we can really say “failures” yet. We’ve only been in for 100 days. Somebody said “inflation.” You’re not going to bring down inflation in three months.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a perspective on the timeframe for evaluating Trump's policies, relevant to the focus on his first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: Inflation has been horrible, but there’s no way you’re going to get it down so quickly. I would say, if anything, taxes, tariffs.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses inflation and tariffs, directly related to the economic focus of Trump's first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: The government has spent more in the past 100 days than they did the year prior, same 100 days. So I think DOGE has been a flop. Very disappointing. Promised a lot. Didn’t deliver.
annotations.reason: This paragraph critiques government spending under Trump, relevant to evaluating his first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: Letting the hostile media entice him into conflict all the time.
annotations.reason: This paragraph comments on Trump's relationship with the media, relevant to his first 100 days in office.

annotations.paragraph: Threatening entitlements and wiping out key agencies of government.
annotations.reason: This is a vague generalization without specific context or details.

annotations.paragraph: When you talk about stocks and you talk about the economy, we have to think about consistency. There can’t just be these knee-jerk reactions to things. “Oh, we’re going to have tariffs. Oh, wait. Let’s walk that back.” You can’t govern that way.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary on Trump's governance style related to tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: I would echo that. How can a business plan what’s going to happen in the future when the tariff situation is constantly changing up and down? It’s awful. He’s the one that caused this. And that’s why it is the way it is.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific criticism of Trump's tariff policy and its impact on business planning.

annotations.paragraph: It’s the tariffs. He probably should have negotiated and talked to our allies first to come up with a united front against China.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a specific suggestion regarding Trump's tariff strategy.

annotations.paragraph: Does anyone on this Zoom think that the Trump tariff policy has been a success? Brandi and Brian, tell me why.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a direct question about the success of Trump's tariff policy.

annotations.paragraph: I understand why he’s doing it, but I don’t know if it’s going to help us in the long run. I think we have to give it a little time.
annotations.reason: This paragraph reflects the uncertainty and patience of a former Democratic voter regarding Trump's policies.

annotations.paragraph: You got to give it time, and you’ve got to understand that it’s all negotiating tactics.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the voter's perspective on Trump's negotiation strategies.

annotations.paragraph: He’s trying to get something fairer. There’s no American goods in foreign countries. And he’s trying to right that wrong. And I absolutely admire that, and I hope it works out for us, but it’s also a very scary time.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the voter's admiration and concerns about Trump's trade policies.

annotations.paragraph: Some of these negotiations probably should have happened behind closed doors, instead of dumping it out to get the big splash at the 6 o’clock news.
annotations.reason: This paragraph critiques Trump's public negotiation tactics, relevant to the voter's perspective.

annotations.paragraph: Donald Trump has always been careless with his words.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a general critique of Trump's communication style without specific context.

annotations.paragraph: Yeah, he’s not going to do anything behind closed doors. That’s just not his personality.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct commentary on Trump's transparency, which is relevant to understanding voter perceptions.

annotations.paragraph: He’s the most transparent president ever. Let’s be honest.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a perspective on Trump's transparency, contributing to the discussion of his presidency.

annotations.paragraph: Yeah, but Matt you voted against him in 2016 and 2020.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about a participant's voting history, which is relevant to understanding shifts in voter behavior.

annotations.paragraph: I was in the union then. I voted for who the union people told me to vote for.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives insight into the influence of unions on voting decisions, relevant to the discussion of voter shifts.

annotations.paragraph: If someone were to ask you to describe Donald Trump in one sentence, based on the first 100 days, how would you describe him?
annotations.reason: This paragraph sets up a question for discussion, relevant to understanding perceptions of Trump's early presidency.

annotations.paragraph: Chaotic, knee-jerky.
annotations.reason: This is a brief opinion that lacks context or elaboration.

annotations.paragraph: A businessman.
annotations.reason: This is a vague statement without context or elaboration.

annotations.paragraph: Very bold and very determined.
annotations.reason: This is a general opinion without specific context or elaboration.

annotations.paragraph: I think he’s been a showman, but he’s actually been probably a little more reserved than he was four years ago.
annotations.reason: This provides a specific opinion comparing Trump's behavior now to four years ago.

annotations.paragraph: A bit short-sighted, especially with regard to China. And they have much more endurance.
annotations.reason: This offers a specific critique of Trump's policy towards China.

annotations.paragraph: Donald Trump is arrogant, but I know he’s trying to win for all of us.

annotations.paragraph: He’s too hung up in his image.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a specific critique of Trump's focus on his image from a former Democratic voter.

annotations.paragraph: I would say arrogant and narcissistic. There’s no other choice.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a personal opinion on Trump's character from a former Democratic voter.

annotations.paragraph: Charismatic, but too bombastic and empty-hearted.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives a nuanced opinion on Trump's personality from a former Democratic voter.

annotations.paragraph: Aggressive to get his plan started.

annotations.paragraph: I would say erratic and driven by his ego.
annotations.reason: This provides a direct opinion from a former Democratic voter about Trump's behavior, relevant to understanding their perspective.

annotations.paragraph: Let’s say Donald Trump is listening to this conversation and you’re looking at him straight in the eye. What would you tell him?
annotations.reason: This is a hypothetical question that does not provide new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Slow down. Keep the level of aggression but slow it down and pace yourself a little bit more.
annotations.reason: This is a direct suggestion to Trump from a former Democratic voter, relevant to their views on his presidency.

annotations.paragraph: I like the slowdown, but I also think to rely on the people he put in his cabinet. Listen to people.
annotations.reason: This provides insight into the voter's opinion on Trump's leadership style and decision-making.

annotations.paragraph: Take advice from the experts, both in his cabinet and in the Congress.
annotations.reason: This is a suggestion from a voter on how Trump should govern, relevant to the discussion of his presidency.

annotations.paragraph: Delegate. Trust the others that work with him, and he doesn’t have to centralize everything.
annotations.reason: This is a vague suggestion without specific context or relevance to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: You can get the job done. Just tone down the arrogance.
annotations.reason: This is a general statement lacking specific context or relevance to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Choose your words more carefully and understand your influence on the American people and the stock market.
annotations.reason: This is a general suggestion without specific context or relevance to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Put the American people first and leave a legacy that you can be proud of.
annotations.reason: This is a vague suggestion without specific context or relevance to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Listen to the leaders that he appointed for the specific positions that they’re in and see what they have to say. He picked them for a reason.
annotations.reason: This is a general suggestion without specific context or relevance to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Get disrupting. The status quo hasn’t been good for the last 25 years.
annotations.reason: This is a vague generalization and does not provide specific insights related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Stop blaming Biden all the time. It weakens his point. It weakens what he’s trying to do.
annotations.reason: This is a low-information statement that does not directly relate to the headline's focus on Trump's first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: Of all the actions that Trump and the administration have taken over the last 100 days or so, have any of them affected you directly, personally?
annotations.reason: This question sets up for personal anecdotes relevant to the headline's focus on Trump's impact.

annotations.paragraph: My wife is from Nigeria, and we’re waiting for her visa so she can come to the U.S. And that process has actually sped up under Trump. And our hope is that the process, which is currently about two years, speeds up even more.
annotations.reason: This provides a personal account of how Trump's policies have directly affected an individual, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: I’m a small-business owner. And so these tariffs are actually a very, very scary thing. Being a small-business owner is hard enough, and I’m very afraid that it’s about to get a lot harder.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a personal perspective on the impact of Trump's tariffs, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Have they hit your bottom line or your ability to invest yet?
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a question that sets up the discussion about the impact of Trump's policies, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Oh, yeah. We’re going to have to start looking at alternatives. We’ve already lined up other manufacturers. We’ve tried to look at manufacturing in the U.S., which is still too expensive. We’re in crisis mode.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary on the economic impact of Trump's policies, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: There’s a fair number of you who don’t seem to think that America is great again. You’re very nervous about the country. Can you explain why?
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a question that could lead to relevant insights from the focus group.

annotations.paragraph: We’re not there yet.
annotations.reason: This is a vague response without specific information.

annotations.paragraph: I don’t think we’re there yet, but I don’t want to blame him for it.
annotations.reason: This provides a personal perspective on Trump's impact, relevant to the focus group discussion.

annotations.paragraph: It’s too tribal. Nobody talks to each other anymore. This is the most divided Congress that I can ever remember. And the hypocrisy that’s coming out on both sides? It’s almost like politicians don’t think that what they say now is on the internet forever.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a critique of the political climate, relevant to the discussion of Trump's presidency.

annotations.paragraph: I’m optimistic. I’m hopeful. I feel like we need to give it time. Change never happens overnight. I’m going to be positive that the economy is going to get better because, to me, it has been like a dumpster fire.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the voter's perspective on Trump's impact on the economy.

annotations.paragraph: How has the economy hit you, Brandi?
annotations.reason: This is a question prompting further discussion, not providing new information.

annotations.paragraph: I’m a school speech pathologist, so it’s about to hit us in the schools. But inflation’s just really hit me.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific personal impact of economic changes under Trump.

annotations.paragraph: David, you talked earlier about a desire for Trump maybe to pump the brakes a little bit.
annotations.reason: This is a prompt for further discussion, not providing new information.

annotations.paragraph: We do need change. But kicking down the door and rolling out all these executive orders? What is going to happen in Congress for these changes to actually become permanent changes that our country is going to reap the benefits from? So that things don’t just go back to how they were when Congress or the presidency changes hands?
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses concerns about the permanence of Trump's changes, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: How many of you have faith in this current Congress to help steer the country in the right direction? [No one raises a hand.]
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the participants' lack of faith in Congress, which is relevant to understanding their political views.

annotations.paragraph: I just have no faith in them. Our government has not represented us very well.
annotations.reason: This statement reflects a participant's dissatisfaction with the government, relevant to the discussion of political opinions.

annotations.paragraph: Brian, Congress is run by Republicans who are allies of Trump. Do you have faith in them?
annotations.reason: This question is relevant as it probes the participant's views on the Republican-led Congress, which is part of the discussion.

annotations.paragraph: That’s a little bit to be seen. I’m not sure yet.
annotations.reason: This response indicates uncertainty about the Republican Congress, relevant to the participant's political perspective.

annotations.paragraph: If Congress was listening to you right now, what would you tell them?
annotations.reason: This question is relevant as it seeks to understand the participants' direct messages to Congress, reflecting their political concerns.

annotations.paragraph: Care about your constituents and don’t be afraid of Donald Trump.
annotations.reason: This is a vague generalization and does not provide specific insights or facts.

annotations.paragraph: Do you think they are afraid of him?
annotations.reason: This is a low-information question without context or elaboration.

annotations.paragraph: Oh, yeah. I think that they’re very afraid. I think that they feel intimidated and pressured to vote certain ways. I think everybody that has power right now is basically influenced by him. And if they feel differently or think differently, that is a threat.
annotations.reason: This provides insight into the perceived influence of Trump on political figures, relevant to the discussion of his impact.

annotations.paragraph: I’d say the same thing: Don’t be afraid. Stand up for what you think is important.
annotations.reason: This is a vague generalization and does not provide specific insights or facts.

annotations.paragraph: I’d say do the right thing, no matter who it offends.
annotations.reason: This is a vague generalization and does not provide specific insights or facts.

annotations.paragraph: Congress needs to reclaim their authority. The president can’t run the country under emergency order on everything.
annotations.reason: This paragraph does not directly address the main premise of the article about former Democratic voters' opinions on Trump.

annotations.paragraph: There has to be a rebuilding of the Democratic leadership or at least ideals that Democrats and Republicans share through the Congress, so that things can move forward.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is relevant as it discusses potential changes needed in the Democratic Party to win back voters.

annotations.paragraph: You all voted for Democratic candidates in the past and then voted for Trump in 2024. What do the Democrats need to do to win you back in future elections?
annotations.reason: This paragraph is relevant as it directly addresses the main question of the article about winning back former Democratic voters.

annotations.paragraph: They have to stop dabbling in the markets. Everybody in Congress, the Senate. And they need youth.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is relevant as it provides specific opinions on what changes are needed to win back voters.

annotations.paragraph: Democrats need to listen. I don’t feel like anybody’s listening anymore. We want youth. We want someone we can identify with.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is relevant as it offers insights into voter sentiments and what they desire from the Democratic Party.

annotations.paragraph: Right now, whatever Trump wants to do, they have to automatically take the opposite. Show the country that they’re willing to work together on issues that both sides agree on.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the political dynamics and the need for bipartisanship, which is relevant to understanding the perspectives of former Democratic voters.

annotations.paragraph: You’ve got Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez out there. And they kind of left me, I guess. You could say the Democratic Party left me. We need to come back to the middle.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into why some former Democratic voters shifted their support, which is relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: I think they need better candidates. Youth and strength and knowledge and a clear plan forward.
annotations.reason: This paragraph suggests improvements for the Democratic Party, which is relevant to the discussion of winning back former voters.

annotations.paragraph: I’ve agreed with a lot of the things people said about bipartisanship. I want to see all that wrapped up in a hopeful and positive candidate, like Barack Obama. Someone with a clear vision of the future that allows me to feel hopeful again.
annotations.reason: This paragraph reflects on the qualities desired in political candidates, relevant to the focus on voter perspectives.

annotations.paragraph: And Kamala Harris was not that with her politics of joy?
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a rhetorical question that does not add substantial information to the discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Not even close. Not even close.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is vague and does not provide any new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Not close.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is vague and does not provide any new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: I want to see moral and economic leadership and a sense of gravitas that I just haven’t sensed since Hillary Clinton and Bill Clinton.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a personal opinion on leadership qualities, relevant to the discussion of political preferences.

annotations.paragraph: I definitely think they should go back to the basics. I feel like the Democrats put out a lot of false hope to the working class and to students. Student loan forgiveness. They made a whole big thing about that. And then to come in and have everything thrown out — I don’t think they were prepared for that.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses specific criticisms of the Democratic Party, relevant to understanding why voters may have shifted to Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Why did you all abandon the Democrats?
annotations.reason: This question is directly relevant to the article's focus on understanding voter shifts.

annotations.paragraph: It wasn’t working. My life wasn’t getting better. The future wasn’t looking great.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides personal insight into why a voter switched to Trump, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Their attack on the Second Amendment, and I didn’t trust their candidates. You never knew where they stood.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains a specific reason for distrust in Democratic candidates, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: I just think the party became ridiculous and they weren’t representing what most of America wanted.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general opinion on the Democratic Party's representation, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Illegal immigration. I’m trying to bring a spouse to the United States legally, and there are unbelievable hurdles. And yet you see people come over time and time again. They did not care.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses personal experiences with immigration, relevant to the article's focus on immigration issues.

annotations.paragraph: I don’t feel as though Kamala was an active vice president. To trust her as a president was not something that I was going to do.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a personal opinion on Kamala Harris, which is not directly relevant to the article's focus on Trump's first 100 days.

annotations.paragraph: Terrible candidate. All she did was giggle. You never really heard what she stood for.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct opinion on a candidate, contributing to the discussion of why voters switched to Trump.

annotations.paragraph: The too-far-left social policy and poor economic policy. I think that we got too far away from, honestly, some good old-fashioned Christian values in America. I think that when we start getting into gender fluidity and those types of ideas, that doesn’t represent me anymore, morally.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific reasons for the voter's shift, relevant to the article's focus on political opinions.

annotations.paragraph: I just feel that Kamala was more about rhetoric than about action.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a critique of a political figure, relevant to understanding voter sentiment.

annotations.paragraph: I don’t really believe Trump is a Republican, and I don’t believe that the Democrats had any real path forward. He had some ideas. He had some suggestions. And I don’t believe the Democrats really did this time around.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses perceptions of political parties and Trump's appeal, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Which party is better for working-class Americans? Who says the Democratic Party? [Samantha raises a hand.] Who says the Republican Party? [Seven others raise a hand.] What happened to the Democratic Party where it lost so many working-class Americans?
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights a key discussion point about party alignment with working-class interests, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: It was NAFTA. Bill Clinton. That’s what it was. That’s why we don’t have as many jobs here as we used to. All those businesses went abroad.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a specific reason for the shift in voting behavior, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: It didn’t hit me until Biden became president. I hadn’t noticed that the economy was somewhat better prior. And then it went to hell.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a personal perspective on economic changes, relevant to the discussion of voter sentiment.

annotations.paragraph: When you bring in 15 million, 20 million people to compete with working-class and union wages, it’s going to lower the working class and the hourly wage of hard-working construction workers, electricians, plumbers. All those illegal aliens are taking away those jobs. And Democrats were supposedly for the working class. But if you’re bringing in 20 million people, how are you for the working class?
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses immigration and its perceived impact on jobs, directly related to the article's theme.

annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a question relevant to the discussion of how Democrats can win back voters.

annotations.paragraph: Don’t be afraid to be bold. Trump gets a lot of attention because he’s not as diplomatic. And I described the Democratic Party as the party of diplomacy. I would say: Be unconventional, lean more toward Obama, more progressive, more aggressive and bold.

annotations.paragraph: Hakeem Jeffries. He just seems like he’s pretty level-headed. He is pretty left of center, but he’s got a lot of strong ideas about the future, which I like.

annotations.paragraph: Pete Buttigieg. Every time he has a conversation on TV, he is so level and smart, and he’s never going away from his facts. I feel like he could really, really do some good in the future.

annotations.paragraph: Trump has targeted a number of institutions, places like Harvard and Columbia, different law firms, even the N.I.H. and different government agencies. Are there any of these institutions that you feel like he’s either right or wrong to try to pressure and change?

annotations.paragraph: The Ivy League schools — I don’t know what we’re giving them money for, with all the endowments and stuff they get.

annotations.paragraph: Regardless of how much is saved, the government needs to be run like corporate America. We need to cut back.

annotations.paragraph: D.E.I. — Trump has made it his mission to eliminate it from various elements of government. So let’s get a show of hands. How many of you support the president’s efforts to eliminate D.E.I.? Raise your hands. [Everyone but Daniel raises a hand.]

annotations.paragraph: Yeah, I support that. I think the Democratic Party has gone so overboard on all of that stuff. Just crazy. And I support what he’s doing there.

annotations.paragraph: Yeah, on board 100 percent. I think it should be based on merit, not on any of the other demographics.

annotations.paragraph: I love what he’s doing with the government and cleaning up spending. annotations.paragraph: I remember thinking, “I’m worried he’ll go too far.” And 100 days in, I guess I’m worried he’s going to go too far.

annotations.paragraph: Me, too. I definitely said to myself, “How is it that the first seven days he’s in office, things are happening and Biden went through almost his entire term with nothing happening?”

annotations.paragraph: I was never a believer of the word “the swamp” before. But now I’m seeing a big change of trying to change the way Washington works. So to me, it’s refreshing.
